title-group.article-title: Platelet-Rich Plasma Treatment for Lateral Epicondylitis: Letter to the Editor

author-notes.corresp: John J. Wilson, MD, MS (e-mail: wilson@ortho.wisc.edu).

permissions.copyright-holder: American Orthopaedic Society for Sports Medicine

body.p: In their randomized controlled trial (RCT), Dr Krogh and colleagues8 compared platelet-rich plasma (PRP) injection with glucocorticoid and saline injections for chronic lateral epicondylosis (CLE). Improvements in primary and secondary outcomes were not statistically different between groups, and the study was reported as negative. We commend the authors for their rigorous 12-month study; they acknowledge the difficulties associated with participant attrition and the need to report limited 3-month data. They concluded that they were unable to corroborate prior positive results for PRP but that both PRP and corticosteroid injections are safe.

Our academic university practice uses PRP for treatment of tendinopathies; the authors’ conclusions differ from our experience. In the interest of clinical context and rigorous future assessment of PRP, we offer the following observations and suggestions.
We postulate that 4 elements in the design, conduct, and reporting of this study may have minimized the ability to meaningfully detect a potential effect of PRP.

list-item.p: Our clinical experience is that improvement in pain and functional outcomes after PRP treatment can be slow; often effects are not evident until after 3 months or more. Studies that have evaluated common extensor tendon healing after therapeutic injections, including PRP, have consistently demonstrated that best effects were not evident until an average of 6 months after treatment.9,7,13 We agree with the authors’ cautious approach to interpretation of these 3-month data.

The potential biological effect of the PRP injection, even in the early stages of healing, may have been minimized by 2 aspects of the protocol. First, the researchers injected a large volume (10-15 mL) of lidocaine into the peritendinous tissue in all subjects, which departs from the standard of care for most physicians using PRP.9 Carofino et al3 have reported that lidocaine exerts inhibitory effects on tenocyte proliferation in the presence of PRP. Second, sodium citrate was used as an anticoagulant in the preparation of PRP, which is reported to have inhibitory effects on platelet aggregation and activation in PRP.2,6 These procedures may have rendered PRP less active or even inactive. The results at 3 months and the per protocol analysis at 12 months demonstrating no difference between saline and PRP groups may therefore be partially due to inadvertent diminution of PRP effect.

The Patient-Rated Tennis Elbow Evaluation (PRTEE) outcome measure was used in an unconventional manner, and the power calculation was based on a very large between-group effect on the PRTEE pain subscale, not the instrument as a whole. Therefore, the assessment and analysis scheme, although well described, may be overly optimistic and therefore unlikely to detect a statistically significant difference between groups even under ideal clinical circumstances. Specifically, the PRTEE is designed as a 100-point scale12 (50 points for pain and 100/2 points for function), not the 150 points reported here. The minimal clinical important difference (“much better” or “completely recovered”) on the PRTEE has been reported as an 11-point change on the 100-point PRTEE as a whole.10 The authors powered their study to detect a difference in change between groups of 10 out of only 50 possible points on the PRTEE pain subscale, a very large effect size among a small number of points, the statistically significant detection of which seems unlikely even if the PRP effect was very large. And although scales can be appropriately modified, the use of a 150-point analysis of the PRTEE may render these results less comparable with studies using the more conventional 100-point method.

The authors’ conclusion that both PRP and corticosteroid injections can be used safely may be premature (for PRP) or incorrect (for corticosteroids). Although this study does not report adverse events, it is also not powered to detect rare occurrences; the short duration further limits the claim to overall safety. More important, the comparison with glucocorticoid injections, although standard in lateral epicondylosis research, has become more controversial in recent years. Although data support some effectiveness for short-term pain relief in the treatment of epicondylosis,1 evidence is building that corticosteroid injections result in worse outcomes, compared, for example, with physical therapy alone at 1 year.4

body.p: Determining the optimal trial design and choice of control treatment against which to assess therapies for CLE remains challenging, given the clinical popularity of corticosteroid injection, the need for a blindable control, and the nontrivial clinical effect of saline injections.11 Clinical trialists have acknowledged the pressure to select against study designs with clinically relevant but nonblindable control groups, such as exercise, in the interest of perceived methodological rigor.5 Determining the effect of PRP in meaningful clinical settings may thereby suffer. Future assessment of PRP would benefit from comparison with both saline control and noninjection standard of care control groups.

body.p: We thank Dr Wilson and colleagues for raising important points in relation to the clinical use of PRP in the treatment of lateral epicondylitis. Issues such as PRP preparation technique, dose-response of PRP, use of citrate to prevent coagulation, volume of local anesthetics, injection technique, observation period, and standardized outcome parameters are not internationally standardized and differ between previous studies.5,9,10,14

As discussed in the article, tendon healing is a slow process, and we agree with Dr Wilson and colleagues that patients should ideally be followed as long as possible. In our study, the pain level made it difficult and ethically debatable to keep patients in a blinded RCT study for longer than 3 months.7 The previous 4 studies assessing treatment with PRP for lateral epicondylitis had already reported a pain-reducing effect at 3 months when compared with baseline.5,9,10,14 These results, however, are difficult to interpret since only 1 trial, a cohort study,9 included a placebo group.

In 3 of 4 previous lateral epicondylitis trials investigating PRP effect, a local anesthetic was applied intratendinously9,10 and/or peritendiously,5,9 and in our recent network meta-analysis, 12 of 17 trials (70%) used local anesthetics.6 This finding demonstrates that local anesthetics are frequently used in lateral epicondylitis research. In the prestudy phase we found that injecting PRP into the common extender tendon was very painful. This might be explained by the relatively large volume of PRP injected into a small tendon area. However, we used 3 mL of PRP, as done in the other studies.7

In the previous 4 in vivo PRP studies, up to 2 mL of local anesthetic was used followed by injection of 3 mL of PRP. Three of the studies used sodium citrate in unknown concentrations. First, we infiltrated with 10 mL of local anesthetics peritendinously, followed by injection of 3 mL of PRP. Our technique used a larger volume of local anesthetics, and we cannot rule out a possible negative effect of this but it is not likely. Second, we stabilized the platelets with sodium citrate as done in the other studies, and again we cannot rule out a negative effect. However, possible negative effects of citrate and local anesthetics on the healing of tendons are based on data from in vitro studies,2,3 and in vivo studies are needed to answer questions about the clinical effect.

In our study we used the PRTEE questionnaire.8,11 Our primary outcome was change in pain, which is why we used the pain subscale and function subscale separately as allowed by the developer of this questionnaire.8 We did not, however, report the total PRTEE score. We agree that it might be easier to compare different studies if only the total PRTEE score is reported as a primary outcome.

In the Safety section in our article we reported side effects as observed in our study. We agree that hypothetical speculations regarding rare occurrences are unlikely to be recognized in small trials. It would take very large studies and long follow-up periods to detect rare occurrences. In lateral epicondylitis research, the best chance of detecting rare side effects would be by collecting data from various trials. In a recent network meta-analysis, we looked at the comparative effectiveness of various injection therapies and side effects.6

Tendons have natural healing properties over long time,1,4,6,13 and no well-documented, long-lasting, effective injection therapies for lateral epicondylitis are available.6 Before any recommendations can be made on the use of PRP in the treatment of lateral epicondylitis, it is necessary to conduct more well-designed RCTs following the consort recommendations12 and compare active treatment to placebo for 6 to 12 months.
